content.user_title: Guide engineering leadership and technology decisions
content.value_statement: Technology leaders need frameworks for technical debt assessment, team scaling, architecture decisions, and engineering metrics. This skill provides calculators, templates, and guides for CTO-level strategic planning and execution.
actual_capabilities: Analyze technical debt across architecture, code quality, infrastructure, security, and performance categories with prioritized action plans
Calculate optimal team scaling plans including hiring targets, role distributions, budget projections, and risk assessments
Provide Architecture Decision Record (ADR) templates and frameworks for documenting architectural choices
Implement engineering metrics including DORA metrics, productivity indicators, team health metrics, and executive dashboards
Evaluate technology vendors and platforms using structured criteria matrices for technical, business, and operational assessment
limitations: Does not execute code or interact with live systems - provides guidance and templates only
Does not integrate with project management tools like Jira or GitHub
Does not collect or visualize real-time engineering data from CI/CD pipelines
Does not provide legal, financial, or compliance advice

use_cases.title: Assess technical debt
use_cases.description: Prioritize debt reduction efforts across architecture, security, and performance with effort estimates and risk assessments

use_cases.title: Plan team growth
use_cases.description: Calculate hiring plans, budget projections, and optimal team structures for scaling engineering organizations

use_cases.title: Document decisions
use_cases.description: Create Architecture Decision Records using templates that capture context, alternatives, and consequences

prompt_templates.title: Tech Debt Assessment
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze technical debt for a legacy e-commerce platform with monolithic architecture, 75% test coverage gaps, manual deployments, and security concerns. Provide prioritized action items and effort estimates.

prompt_templates.title: Team Scaling Plan
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a hiring plan to scale from 25 engineers to 75 over 4 quarters. Include role distribution, budget projections, and risk mitigation strategies.

prompt_templates.title: Architecture Decision
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an ADR template for choosing between microservices and modular monolith for a growing startup. Include decision drivers and trade-offs.

prompt_templates.title: Vendor Evaluation
prompt_templates.prompt: Evaluate Kubernetes vs Amazon ECS for a mid-size company planning multi-cloud deployment. Include technical, business, and operational criteria.

output_examples.input: Analyze technical debt for our legacy e-commerce platform
output: Category breakdown: Architecture 75%, Security 78%, Code Quality 65%
Top priority: Security audit and patching (immediate)
Key risks: Potential data breach vulnerability, developer productivity declining
Estimated effort: 1200 story points, 15 sprints, 8-12 developers needed

output_examples.input: Plan scaling from 25 to 75 engineers in 4 quarters
output: Timeline: Q1 +20 hires, Q2 +18, Q3 +17, Q4 +15
Role priorities: 3 Engineering Managers, 5 Tech Leads, 12 Senior Engineers
Budget: $4.2M annual salary cost, $600K recruiting cost
Risks: Rapid growth dilution (mitigation: mentorship program), Compressed timeline
Team structure: 8 teams of 6-8 engineers with dedicated product and QA support

output_examples.input: Create ADR for microservices vs monolith decision
output: ADR Template includes: Context, Decision Drivers, Considered Options, Outcome
Positive consequences: Independent deployment, service scaling, fault isolation
Negative consequences: Operational complexity, network latency, data consistency
Mitigation strategies: Invest in DevOps, careful service boundaries, event sourcing

best_practices: Use the technical debt analyzer quarterly to track progress and adjust debt reduction capacity allocations
Document all significant architectural decisions using ADR templates to maintain institutional knowledge
Combine DORA metrics with team health metrics for a complete view of engineering organization performance
anti_patterns: Do not use lines of code or commit counts as productivity metrics - they encourage counterproductive behavior
Avoid treating a single metric as the complete truth - combine leading and lagging indicators
Do not ignore team feedback on metrics - let teams participate in choosing and refining metrics that matter

faq.question: How do I run the technical debt analyzer?
faq.answer: Execute python scripts/tech_debt_analyzer.py to run the analyzer with default example data or modify the example_system dictionary with your actual system configuration.

faq.question: What DORA metrics should my team track?
faq.answer: Track deployment frequency, lead time for changes, mean time to recovery, and change failure rate. Elite performers deploy multiple times daily with under one hour lead time.

faq.question: How do I calculate team scaling needs?
faq.answer: Use the team scaling calculator with current state (headcount, roles, velocity) and growth targets (target headcount, timeline). It generates hiring plans and budget projections.

faq.question: What is an Architecture Decision Record?
faq.answer: An ADR documents significant architectural decisions with context, alternatives considered, chosen option, and consequences. It preserves institutional knowledge about why systems are built a certain way.

faq.question: How do I evaluate technology vendors?
faq.answer: Use the evaluation framework with criteria across technical (performance, scalability, security), business (cost, ROI, vendor stability), and operational (ease of use, documentation, community) dimensions.

faq.question: What Python tools are included?
faq.answer: Two calculator scripts: tech_debt_analyzer.py analyzes system debt and generates prioritized actions, team_scaling_calculator.py plans hiring and organizational structure for growth.
